TI Antimicrobial Susceptibility Patterns and Characterization of Clinical
   Isolates of Staphylococcus aureus in Immunocompromised Cancer Patients
   Undergoing Chemotherapy in Pakistan
SO JOURNAL OF CHEMOTHERAPY
LA English
DT Article
DE Staphylococcus aureus infections; cancer patients; methicillin-resistant
   Staphylococcus aureus; antimicrobial resistance
ID UNITED-STATES; EPIDEMIOLOGY; INFECTIONS; BACTEREMIA; RESISTANCE;
   HOSPITALS; EUROPE; SENTRY
AB Cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy are highly prone to infections because of suppression of their immune system. In the present study, the activity of fluoroquinolones, cephalosporins, glycopeptides and oxazolidinones was evaluated in Staphylococcus aureus strains by broth dilution method according to Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI), USA guidelines. The frequency of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) and methicillin-sensitive S. aureus (MSSA) strains was 67% and 33% respectively. The MIC50 and MIC90 of isolates were ciprofloxacin 8 and 32 mu g/ml for MRSA, 8 and 16 mu g/ml for MSSA levofloxacin 8 and 16 mu g/ml for MRSA and MSSA, gatifloxacin 4 and 16 mu g/ml for MRSA and 4 and 8 mu g/ml for MSSA. MIC50 and MIC90 of vancomycin and linzolid were 1 and 2 mu g/ml, 2 and 4 mu g/ml for both MRSA and MSSA strains respectively. This study shows a high prevalence of and resistance in MRSA. However, vancomycin and linezolid were highly active and could be used for treating MRSA infections.
C1 [Younus, A.] Univ Punjab, Inst Biochem & Biotechnol, Lahore, Pakistan.

TI Effect of phosphate complexation on Cd2+ sorption by manganese dioxide
   (beta-MnO2)
SO JOURNAL OF COLLOID AND INTERFACE SCIENCE
LA English
DT Article
DE beta-MnO2; Cd2+ sorption; Phosphate complexation; PZC; Thermodynamic
   parameters; Van't Hoff equation
ID GOETHITE ALPHA-FEOOH; ELECTROLYTE-SOLUTIONS; SURFACE-PROPERTIES; COBALT
   DESORPTION; METAL ADSORPTION; CADMIUM SORPTION; LEAD SORPTION;
   SEA-WATER; FERRIHYDRITE; OXIDE
AB Sorption of metal ions on oxide/hydroxide surfaces mediates the fate and transport of these ions in many natural systems. These metallic ions often exist in bulk in the aqueous phase as complexes with inorganic and organic ligands. In the present study, we investigated the sorption properties of manganese dioxide in the presence of phosphate which is thought to be one of the most important complex forming species. The surface area, point of zero charge and structural morphology of the solid manganese dioxide were determined. Cd2+ sorption studies were carried out on manganese dioxide as a function of pH. temperature and phosphate concentration. Cd2+ sorption increased with increasing pH, temperature and phosphate concentration. It was found that phosphate formed both outer and inner sphere complexes via metal and ligand-like adsorption. The Langmuir equation was applied to describe the data and from the constants of this equation different thermodynamic parameters such as Delta H-0, Delta S-0 and Delta G(0) were evaluated. (C) 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

TI Elevated frequency of p53 genetic mutations and AgNOR values in squamous
   cell carcinoma
SO JOURNAL OF CUTANEOUS PATHOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
ID NUCLEOLAR ORGANIZER REGIONS; PROTEIN EXPRESSION; SKIN-CANCER; NORMAL
   MUCOSA; NECK-CANCER; HEAD; LESIONS; BENIGN; DYSPLASIA; NETWORK
AB Epidermal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a common malignancy in Pakistan. We hypothesize that it is characterized by higher frequency of p53 genetic mutations and increased AgNOR values compared with squamous cell papilloma (SCP) and basal cell carcinoma (BCC).
   To test our hypothesis, 140 skin biopsies (including 20 normal skin, 20 SCP, 20 BCC and 80 SCC samples of various grades) were examined for p53 mutations using immunohistochemistry (IHC) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR). AgNOR staining was used for histological determination of AgNOR index.
   Both markers were undetectable in normal skin and were low in SCP. They were upregulated in BCC and SCC. PCR experiments revealed p53 mutations in 70% and 96.25% of BCC and SCC, respectively. Higher AgNOR values were seen in SCC than in BCC (mean AgNOR count = 5.81 +/- 31 and 8.36 +/- 19; percentage of AgNOR was 43.5% and 53% in BCC and SCC, respectively). Finally, p53 IHC score was found to be related to the AgNOR index in the histological grading of BCC and SCC (r = +0.983, p < 0.0001).
   Our results suggest that a higher frequency of p53 genetic mutations and increased AgNOR values exist in SCC compared with BCC and SCP. 'Consequently, SCC patients may have poorer prognosis'.
   Bukhari MH, Niazi S, Khaleel ME, Sharif MA, Ghani R, Mehmood MT, Tahseen M, Chaudhry NA, Hasan M. Elevated frequency of p53 genetic mutations and AgNOR values in squamous cell carcinoma.J Cutan Pathol 2009; 36: 220-228. (C) 2008 Blackwell Munksgaard.

AU Raza, SJ
   Ather, H
AF Raza, Syed Johar
   Ather, Hammad
TI Does the Type of Lithotripter Affect Outcomes in Children with Upper
   Tract Urolithiasis?
SO JOURNAL OF ENDOUROLOGY
LA English
DT Article
ID SHOCK-WAVE LITHOTRIPSY; EXTRACORPOREAL LITHOTRIPSY; RENAL STONES;
   EXPERIENCE; CALCULI; MANAGEMENT
AB Purpose: To compare the treatment outcome and short-term safety of electrohydraulic and electromagnetic lithotripters in children.
   Patients and Methods: Comparative analysis of children undergoing shockwave lithotripsy (SWL) with a Dornier MPL 9000 (TM) electrohydraulic lithotripter (EHL)and a Siemens Modularis (TM) electromagnetic lithotripter (EML) was performed. All SWL treatments were performed by a single operator under the supervision of an admitting urologist. The demographic features, stone, and treatment-related parameters, including complications, were analyzed for both groups. Stone-free (SF) rates, re-treatment rate, and efficiency quotient (EQ) were calculated and compared for the two groups.
   Results: Ninety-eight children had SWL for renal and proximal ureteral stones. There were 58 children in the EHL group and 40 in the EML group. There were no statistically significant differences between the groups in terms of age, sex, type of anesthesia, diagnostic modality, site, side, and size of the stones. Number of shock-waves used with EML was greater than with EHL (P < 0.00). SF rate was 95% and 77% for EHL and EML, respectively, with a statistically significant difference (P < 0.00). The re-treatment rate was equal in either group. The complication rate was higher with the EHL compared with the EML, although it did not reach statistical significance. Steinstrasse was the most common complication noted. EQ was 66% for the EHL, in comparison with 53% for the EML.
   Conclusion: The EHL has a better SF and EQ than the EML; however, short-term safety is marginally better with the EML.

TI Milk fatty acid composition of indigenous goat and ewe breeds from
   Sindh, Pakistan
SO JOURNAL OF FOOD COMPOSITION AND ANALYSIS
LA English
DT Article
DE Kamori goat; Pateri goat; Kooka ewes; Kachi ewes; Indigenous breed; Milk
   fatty acids; CLA; Food composition; Pakistan
ID CONJUGATED LINOLEIC-ACID; HOLSTEIN COWS; BRANCHED-CHAIN; JERSEY COWS;
   DAIRY-COWS; PASTURE; SOYBEANS; PROFILE; CATTLE; LIPIDS
AB The present study Was undertaken to evaluate the breed influence oil milk fatty acid (FA) composition, particularly oil the concentration of Conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) from two different indigenous breeds of goats (Pateri and Kamori: n = 30 for each breed) and ewes (Kachi and Kooka: n = 25 for each) from Sindh, Pakistan. All animals were managed together and received the same diet. Statistical significant differences (P < 0.05) in the proportions of individual fatty acids were observed among goat and ewe breeds. Milk fat cis-9, trans-11 CLA concentration from Kamori goats and Kooka ewes were [17-28%] higher when compared to Pateri goats and Kachi ewes, with mean Values of 0.48 g/100 g for goat breeds and 0.82 g/100 g for ewes. The greatest differences (P < 0.01) were observed between the group of saturated fatty acids (SEA) in goat (Pateri and Kamori 64.37 vs. 59.07 g/100 g) and ewe breeds (Kachi and Kooka 66.96 vs. 59.00 g/100 g). The SUM of the mono-unsaturated fatty acids (MUFAs) was lower in Paten goat and Kooka breed ewe as compared to Kamori goats and Kachi ewes (27.60 vs. 31.04 g/100 g and 25.35 vs. 30.33 g/100 g). The proportion of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) did not differ statistically (P > 0.05) among goat and ewe breads, ranging from 2.45 to 3.60 for goats and 2.48 to 3.27 g/100 g for ewes. The present study reveals that the breed has a Pronounced effect on FA composition of goat and ewes milk fat, and in the future genetic selection plans along with improved nutrition program of goats and ewes may result in optimum levels of Various fatty acids in milk. (C) 2008 Elsevier Inc., All rights reserved.
C1 [Talpur, Farah N.; Bhanger, M. I.; Memon, Nusrat N.] Univ Sindh, Natl Ctr Excellence Analyt Chem, Jamshoro 76080, Pakistan.

TI Twin Symmetric E-plane Slab Loaded Waveguide Structure for Point Beam
   Acceleration
SO JOURNAL OF INFRARED MILLIMETER AND TERAHERTZ WAVES
LA English
DT Article
DE Dielectric waveguides; Modal bandwidth; Impedance plane; Closed form
   solution
ID WAKE-FIELD ACCELERATOR; DIELECTRIC STRUCTURES; RECTANGULAR WAVEGUIDES;
   CLASSIFICATION; PROPAGATION; DESIGN; GUN
AB Renewed interest regarding the exploitation of dielectric loaded waveguides in high gradient accelerator structures requires a closed form field formulation as cut-off frequencies and optimisation are problematic for numerical methods. In this paper we will present efficient closed form solution for generic slab loaded waveguide boundary value problems. This solution offers flexibility in a sense that it can be further exploited to derive a Green's function linking transverse field expressions for planar structures. The developed solution is demonstrated for a twin slab E-plane slab loaded structure coupled to a Point source emitter assembly. The emission characteristics of the point source emitter assembly are optimized to generate a high intensity and focused beam to be fed to this E-plane slab loaded waveguide structure for beam acceleration. The field analysis, mode nomenclature, modal hierarchy, modal bandwidth, cut-off plane, impedance plane and dispersion relations for this accelerating structure is included for sake the of completeness.
C1 [Zafar, J.; Gibson, A. A. P.] Univ Manchester, Sch Elect & Elect Engn, Microwave & Commun Syst Res Grp, Manchester M60 1QD, Lancs, England.
   [Masood, K.] INMOL, Dept Phys, Lahore 54600, Pakistan.
   [Zafar, H.] Univ S Asia, Electromagnet & Microwave Res Grp, Lahore 54000, Pakistan.
RP Zafar, J (reprint author), Univ Manchester, Sch Elect & Elect Engn, Microwave & Commun Syst Res Grp, Manchester M60 1QD, Lancs, England.
EM Junaid.Zafar@postgrad.manchester.ac.uk
FU Pakistani Government

   suggestions. Mr. Arthur Haigh and Mr. William Keith contributed to the

   Government HEC scholarship award.

TI Texture, microstructure and magnetic properties of Fe-28Cr-15Co-3.5Mo
   permanent magnet
SO JOURNAL OF MAGNETISM AND MAGNETIC MATERIALS
LA English
DT Article
DE Texture; Microstructure; Anisotropy; Magnetic property; Fe-Cr-Co-Mo
   permanent magnet
ID FE; ALLOYS
AB Crystallographic texture, microstructure and magnetic properties of Fe-28Cr-15Co-3.5Mo alloy were studied as a function of processing parameters. Texture studies revealed that thermo-magnetic aging leads to the development of ideal Goss type, {110} < 001 > and cube type {001} < 010 > textures. The orientation densities of these texture components become stronger after the step-aging treatments. Microstructural features show that improvement in magnetic properties were due to aligning and elongation of ferromagnetic Fe, Co-rich (alpha(1)) particles in the preferred < 100 > directions. Magnetic analysis reveals that magnetic properties of the alloys are directionally dependent and influenced by the choice of thermo-magnetic treatment temperature or time. The maximum values of intrinsic coercive force, remanence and energy product, obtained in the textured magnetic alloy were 68.99 kA/m (867 Oe), 1.12 T (11.2 kG) and 43.2 kJm(3) (5.4MGOe), respectively. (C) 2008 Elsevier B. V. All rights reserved.

TI Isolation and crystal structure of maltol from Abies pindrow
SO JOURNAL OF MEDICINAL PLANTS RESEARCH
LA English
DT Article
DE Abies pindrow; pinaceae; maltol; crystallography
AB Maltol (3-hydroxy-2methyl-4H-pyran-4-one) is neutral, heterocyclic aroma compound and widely known as food additive, antioxidant, metal ions chelator was isolated from leaves of Abies pindrow by column chromatography and its crystal structures and molecular structure was found using x-ray structure analysis and its crystal structure has been determined (C(6)H(6)O(3)).

TI Exact solutions for the flow of a generalized Oldroyd-B fluid induced by
   a constantly accelerating plate between two side walls perpendicular to
   the plate
SO JOURNAL OF NON-NEWTONIAN FLUID MECHANICS
LA English
DT Article
DE Generalized Oldroyd-B fluids; constantly accelerating plate; Side walls;
   Exact solutions
ID MODIFIED DARCYS-LAW; NON-NEWTONIAN FLUID; MAXWELL MODEL; VISCOELASTIC
   FLUIDS; UNSTEADY-FLOW; BURGERS FLUID; POROUS SPACE; ANNULAR PIPE; 1ST
   PROBLEM; MHD FLOW
AB The unsteady flow of an incompressible generalized Oldroyd-B fluid induced by a constantly accelerating plate between two side walls perpendicular to the plate has been studied using Fourier sine and Laplace transforms. The obtained solutions for the velocity field and shear stresses, written in terms of the generalized G and R functions, are presented as sum of the similar Newtonian solutions and the corresponding non-Newtonian contributions. For alpha = beta = 1 and lambda(r) -> lambda these solutions are going to the corresponding Newtonian solutions. Furthermore, the solutions for generalized Maxwell fluids as well as those for ordinary Oldroyd-B and Maxwell fluids, performing the same motion, are also obtained as limiting cases of our general solutions. In the absence of the side walls, namely when the distance between the two walls tends to infinity, the solutions corresponding to the motion over an infinite constantly accelerating plate are recovered. For lambda(r) -> 0 and beta -> 1, these solutions reduce to the known solutions from the literature. Finally, the effect of the material parameters on the velocity profile is spotlighted by means of the graphical illustrations. (C) 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

TI Determination of Sr-90 in environment of district Swat, Pakistan
SO JOURNAL OF RADIOANALYTICAL AND NUCLEAR CHEMISTRY
LA English
DT Article
ID RADIONUCLIDES; SOILS
AB Assessment of Sr-90 is of great interest owing to the fact that this artificially produced radionuclide has high radiological importance because of its high fission yield, chemical similarity to calcium and its relatively long biological and physical half-life. To assess the likely hazard to population, low level Sr-90 in environmental samples is determined using pre-equilibrated tri-butyl phosphate (TBP) solvent and extraction-liquid scintillation procedure. Y-90 is selectively extracted from nitric acid solution into TBP solvent and stripped into aqueous phase as oxalate. The activity is finally measured by low level liquid scintillation counter using Cerenkov radiation. The specific activity is found only in three vegetation samples with average value of 2.86 +/- 1.7 Bq center dot kg(-1) of dry weight. In all other samples analyzed, the activity is below the detectable limit, i.e., 0.03 Bq. Results obtained are comparable with other areas of Pakistan. The chemical recovery of Y-90 varies from 75 to 90% for soil, vegetation and water. The present study provides a general background of the detectable radionuclide for the surveyed area that will be helpful in any radiological emergency.

TI The effects of electropolishing on the nanochannel ordering of the
   porous anodic alumina prepared in oxalic acid
SO JOURNAL OF SOLID STATE ELECTROCHEMISTRY
LA English
DT Article
ID SELF-ORGANIZATION; BORATE SOLUTIONS; PORE FORMATION; OXIDE-FILMS; ARRAY;
   FABRICATION; ELECTRODEPOSITION; SUPERLATTICES; NANOMATERIALS;
   ELECTROLYTE
AB A series of porous anodic alumina has been prepared by anodizing aluminum surface in 0.3 M oxalic acid at different voltages. Prior to anodizing, the surface was pretreated in two different electropolishing electrolytes. One was Brytal solution (15% Na2CO3 and 5% Na3PO4) at 80 C in which the electropolishing was performed at 2 V. This resulted in about 100-150 nm apart random features of 4-5 nm height. The other was the commonly employed perchloric acid-alcohol solution (1:4 ratio by volume), in which the electropolishing was performed at 20 V. The resulting surface comprised nanostripes of 1-2 nm amplitude with a wavelength of about 50 nm. The former pretreatment proved better for self-ordering of the pores at the anodizing voltage of 50-60 V, while the latter pretreatment was found better at the anodizing voltage of 40 V. The improved pore ordering at a given voltage was attributed to the higher pore density as associated with greater repulsive interactions among the pores.

AU Farooq, M

AF Farooq, M.

   Dar, N. U.
TI Improved hybrid position/force controller design of a flexible robot
   manipulator using a sliding observer
SO JOURNAL OF SYSTEMS ENGINEERING AND ELECTRONICS
LA English
DT Article
DE force control; sliding control; Lyapunov stability; robot end effector;
   friction force
AB An improved hybrid position/force controller design of a flexible robot manipulator is presented using a sliding observer. The friction between the end effector and the environment is considered and compensated. For systematic reasons the controller is designed taking into consideration the rigid link subsystems and the flexible joints. The proposed control system satisfies the stability of the two subsystems and copes with the uncertainty of robot dynamics. A sliding observer is designed to estimate the time derivative of the torque applied as input to the rigid part of the robot. For the stability of the observer, it is assumed that the uncertainty of the observed system is bounded. A MRAC algorithm is used for the estimation of the friction forces at the contact point between the end effector and the environment. Finally simulation and experimental results are given, to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed controller.

TI EFFECT OF MINERAL FORTIFICATION ON RHEOLOGICAL PROPERTIES OF WHOLE WHEAT
   FLOUR
SO JOURNAL OF TEXTURE STUDIES
LA English
DT Article
DE Fortification; minerals; rheology; storage; whole wheat flour
ID BREADMAKING QUALITY; BREAD; STORAGE
AB This study was aimed to evaluate the rheological changes that take place in the dough as a result of addition of elemental iron, ferric sodium ethylenediaminetetraacetate, zinc sulphate and zinc oxide in various combinations to whole wheat flour (WWF), packaged in polypropylene woven bags and tin boxes and stored for a period of 60 days under ambient and controlled conditions of temperature and relative humidity. Water absorption (WA) capacity, dough development time (DDT) and dough stability time (DS) of the fortified WWF were measured by farinographic method, and peak viscosity was assessed by viscographic analyses. WA capacity and DDT of flours increased during storage. Fortification significantly (P < 0.05) affected WA, DDT, DS and viscographic characteristics of the flours. Packaging materials (P < 0.05) influenced WA, DDT and DS, while storage condition had only affected viscographic properties of the flours.

TI Analysis of Dolomite of Balochistan (Pakistan) by Using X-Ray
   Fluorescence Spectroscopy (XFS), Simultaneous Differential Thermal
   Analysis (SDTA), Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) and Differential
   Scanning Calorimetry (DSC)
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
AB We deciphered new methods for calculation of thermodynamic parameters from SDTA, TGA & DSC techniques. The stretching of ionic bonds between Mg++ and CO3- and Ca++ and CO3 respectively is conformed on TGA curve at a temperature of 427 degrees K. At 728 K, an ore of dolomite is decomposed due to release of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide gases and the left over Substance is a mixture of MgO and CaO. The ionic bond breaking occurs at 723 degrees K After this, there is reshuffling of ions due to which MgO and CaO are produced at 816 degrees K and 835 K. respectively. The chemists have to think about the chemical processes to separate MgO, a refractory material, from CaO, after baking dolomite upto about 840 degrees K.

TI Effects of Various Buffers and Salt on Color Strength of Reactive Dye
   Sumifix 3RF
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
AB In order to optimize the conditions for reactive dyeing, some variations in the procedure adopted by the industry were taken into consideration. In the present work the effect of buffers like 25% K2HPO4, NaHCO3 + NaOH, KCl + NaOH and Borax + NaOH was studied on the color strength by using Sumifix 3RF yellow (Trichloropyrimidine (TCP) available from Sandoz Corp.) and the results were compared to that of soda ash under the same identical conditions as being employed in textile industry. The effect of salt addition on the fastness of dyes was also studied and is reported in this paper in detail.

TI Effect of Solid Additives on Pyrolysis Behaviour of Makerwal Coal
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID GAS CHROMATOGRAPHY; FLASH PYROLYSIS; VOLATILIZATION; GASIFICATION;
   HYDROCARBONS; BIOMASS; ALKALI
AB The method used in this study provides a quantitative description of the relationship between the chemical structure of coal and the physical and chemical properties of the resultant pyrolysis products (gas, tar, liquid, and char). The purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of inorganic solid additives (Na(2)CO(3), K(2)CO(3), CaCO(3), MgCO(3), Fe(2)O(3) and CaSO(4),), on flash pyrolysis of high volatile bituminous coal samples from Makerwal coalfields by using open tubular type pyrolyzer coupled with gas chromatography. Two different coal samples were selected for this purpose. The sampling apparatus consisted of two traps in order to separate the products into fractions on the basis of their volatility such as tar, liquid, and gaseous fractions. The product yields released from each sample in their raw, de-mineralized and salt treated form were monitored. The gaseous fractions were directly introduced to GC for identification. The gases were C(1)-C(5), hydrocarbons. The pyrolysis was carried out at 690 degrees C. Some evaluations and comparisons, from the results obtained, are presented.
C1 [Ahmad, Tauqeer; Nisar, Jan; Awan, Iftikhar Ahmad] Univ Peshawar, Natl Ctr Excellence Phys Chem, Peshawar 25120, Pakistan.
   [Ahmad, Imtiaz] Islamia Coll, Dept Chem, Peshawar, Pakistan.

TI Study of Limestone from Nizampur Area for Industrial Utilization
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
AB The present research was designed to study the chemical composition of Nizampur limestone and to compare it with the already published data of Khyber Agency, Kohat and Cherat areas of NWFP for industrial utilization. Thirteen samples of limestone were collected from different areas of Nizampur for chemical analysis. The results of the study indicate that as compared to these other areas, Nizampur limestone is most suitable for use in glass, paper, pottery and cement industries.

TI Evaluation Study of Discharge Gas Cooling Water System of Natural Gas
   Compressor Station
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
AB Evaluation of discharge gas cooling system of a natural gas compressor station was studied. Scale deposition potential and corrosion forming tendencies of the cooling water were monitored. Plant operating at high Holding Time Index contributed towards increased scale forming potential of cooling water. Corrosion data analysis showed slightly high rate of corrosion of cooling water that may be due to improper management of acid dosing in the system. Absence of side stream filtration unit might have supported increased turbidity in the system that helped increased growth of microbial colonies in the water. Cooling water quality standards did not support in keeping balance between corrosive and scale forming potential of the circulating water. Therefore, improved limits of cooling water quality standards have been suggested in this work,
C1 [Qureshi, Tahir Imran] NFC Inst Engn & Technol Training, Dept Chem Engn, PO Fertilizer Project, Multan, Pakistan.

   Hafeez, Muhammad Naeem
TI Investigating Catalytic Effect of Titanium Dioxide on Solar Disinfection
   of Water
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
AB In this paper the catalytic effect of titanium dioxide (photo-catalysis) oil solar disinfection of water for inactivation of Fecal coliform bacteria is investigated. Coating of titanium dioxide crystals on glass are exposed to sunlight in two ways: mobilize and immobilize form. An experiment is conducted in consideration for household application. Coating of titanium dioxide on glass rods (immobilize) and rings (mobilize) are positioned in glass bottles filled with water. Inactivation of Fecal coliform is compared with the normal solar disinfection (SODIS) process. Experiment results shows that titanium dioxide enhances the inactivation efficiency of SODIS by 1:1.3:1.8 corresponding to immobilize and mobilize titanium dioxide, respectively, This development is intended for use by small communities, refugee camps, institutions, and during emergency and disaster situations.
C1 [Saleemi, Anwar Rashid; Ramzan, Naveed; Hafeez, Muhammad Naeem] Univ Engn & Technol, Dept Chem Engn, Lahore, Pakistan.
RP Ramzan, N (reprint author), Univ Engn & Technol, Dept Chem Engn, Lahore, Pakistan.
FU Department of Chemical Engineering, University of engineering and
   Technology, Lahore Pakistan
FX Authors are thankful to the Department of Chemical Engineering,
   University of engineering and Technology, Lahore Pakistan for providing
   the necessary grant and facilities for carrying out this research.

TI Investigation of Specific Elemental Distribution in C. sativus L., S.
   melongena L. and M. charantia L. by Atomic Absorption Spectrometry
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID AGRICULTURAL SOIL; MAGNESIUM; DISTRICT
AB C. sativus L. S. melongena L. and M. charantia L. samples were collected from fruit market of Swat and investigated for specific elemental distribution by atomic absorption spectrometry. The results showed that the concentration of metals in all samples were high with skin as compared to without skin. The metals were found in concentration (mg/L) as; Sodium: C. sativus L. with skin (10.2) and without skin (9.5), in S. melongena L. with skin (15.2) and without skin was (8.4) and M charantia L. with skin and seed (4.5) and without skin and seeds was (3.1). Calcium: C. sativus L. with skin (8.1) and without skin (6.0), in S. melongena L with skin (18.4) and without skin was (11.2) and M. charantia L. with skin and seed (8. 1) and without skin and seeds was (6.1). Magnesium: C. sativus L. with skin (7.4) and without skin (6.3), in S. melongena L with skin (10.2) and without skin was (8.4) and M charantia L with skin and seed (4.5) and without skin and seeds was (3.2). Iron: C. sativus L. with skin (3.1) and without skin (2.1), in S. melongena L. with skin (4.2) and without skin was (1.2) and M. charantia L. with skin and seed (3.1) and without skin and seeds was (4.1). Other elements like nickel, copper, zinc, cobalt, cadmium and chromium were found in trace quantities.
C1 [Bangash, Fazlullah Khan] Univ Peshawar, Inst Chem Sci, Peshawar, Pakistan.

TI Mineralogical and Liberation Characteristics of Antimony Ore of Chitral,
   NWFP, Pakistan
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
AB An investigation was carried out to identify the various types of minerals present in antimony ore of Chitral, North West Frontier Province (NWFP), Pakistan and to determine the suitability of the method for its concentration. Ore has been evaluated and characterized by ore microscopy, X-ray diffraction technique and chemical analysis. The major and minor minerals present in the ore were identified. The textural characteristics such as grain size, grain shape and their arrangement in the ore body were also investigated. The degree of liberation of antimony bearing mineral was studied by particles counting method. Based on the mineral assemblage and the textural characteristics, the antimony ore of Chitral is amenable to beneficiation by froth flotation technique.

TI Elemental Analysis of Activated Carbon by EDS Spectrophotometry and
   X-Rays Diffraction
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID HIGH-SURFACE-AREA; ADSORPTION; POTASSIUM; SHELLS; KOH
AB Low cost material (Corncobs-CC, Paulownia tomentosa-PT, Populus caspica-PC and Animal bones-ABC) were utilized for the preparation of activated carbon. Carbon samples were activated chemically and by thermal means (400-1000 degrees C). The samples were characterized by surface area, EDS analysis showed high carbon contents in the samples activated at high temperature as compared to raw and 400 degrees C activated samples while the content of oxygen was found to decrease with the increase in activation temperature. Other elements like, chlorine, silica, iron, magnesium etc were found in trace amounts. The XRD analysis using ORIGIN-50 computer software showed that carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen. boron, chromium, fluorine and nitrogen were present in the carbon samples.
C1 [Bangash, Fazlullah Khan] Univ Peshawar, Inst Chem Sci, Peshawar 25021, Pakistan.

TI Decomposition of Hydrogen Peroxide by Nickel Oxide Powders
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID CATALYTIC DECOMPOSITION; IRON
AB The decomposition of hydrogen peroxide was studied in the presence of monodispersed nickel oxide powders, obtained from the nickel basic carbonate at the calcinations rates of 5, 10, 15, and 20 degrees C/min and on commercial nickel oxide powders. Effect of pH on the decomposition reaction was used to evaluate the mechanism of the decomposition reaction. It was observed that only the surface negative sites were responsible for the observed decomposition of hydrogen peroxide. Rates constants were calculated for the decomposition reaction in the temperature range of 35-50 degrees C and the activation energies were estimated from the Arrhenius plots for all the synthetic and commercial samples of nickel oxides.
C1 Kohat Univ Sci & Technol, Kohat, NWFP, Pakistan.
RP Akhtar, K (reprint author), Kohat Univ Sci & Technol, Kohat, NWFP, Pakistan.

TI Pilot Scale Production of Strontium Sulphate and Strontium Chloride from
   Indigenous Celestite Ore
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
AB Research work has been conducted for pilot scale production of strontium sulphate (SrSO(4)) and strontium chloride (SrCl(2)) from indigenous Celestite ore. This was collected from Khairabad village near Daud Khel and analyzed for Sr contents by Atomic Absorption Spectrometer (AAS). Strontium sulphate was synthesized by the reaction of strontium sulphide with sulphuric acid (H(2)SO(4)) as well as sodium sulphate (Na(2)SO(4)), While strontium chloride was prepared by the reaction of strontium sulphide and hydrochloric acid. The excellent yields of SrSO(4), (88.92%) and SrCl(2) (98.21%) were obtained by the treatment of SrS with Na(2)SO(4) (50% excess than stoichiometric ratio) and with 4 N HCl at 25 degrees C, respectively, The synthesized SrSO(4), was applied as filler and extender in white paints, grey primer and as brightening agent in white paints, SrCl(2) was applied for preparation of SrCrO(4), and also in bricks to make them moisture resistant.
C1 [Bhatti, Khalid Pervez] PCRWR, Minist Sci & Technol, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Amanullah] Govt Coll Univ, Dept Chem, Faisalabad, Pakistan.
   [Ahmed, Riaz] Univ Agr Faisalabad, Dept Chem, Faisalabad, Pakistan.
RP Bhatti, KP (reprint author), PCRWR, Minist Sci & Technol, Islamabad, Pakistan.
FU Pakistan Science Foundation (PSF); National Fertilizer Company (NFC)
   Faisalabad

   project and facilities extended by National Fertilizer Company (NFC)

   (NIBGE) Faisalabad and Department of Mineralogy, Govt. of the Punjab,
   Pakistan. We are also thankful to Khawaja Paints Industry, Faisalabad
   for helping in application as well as testing physicochernical
   parameters.

TI Synthesis and Characterization of Antibacterial Metal [Cu (II), Ni (II),
   Co (II) and Zn (II)] Complexes with Ofloxacin-imines
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID CRYSTAL-STRUCTURE; MANNICH-BASES; ZN(II); NORFLOXACIN; ANTIFUNGAL;
   SCHIFF; CO(II)
AB Some new complexes of Co (II), Ni (II), Cu (H), and Zn (II) with ofloxacin-imines derived from ofloxacin and p-substituted anilines have been prepared and characterized by elemental analysis, magnetic susceptibility, conductance measurement, UV/VIS., and infrared spectroscopy. The ofloxacin-imines, as well as their metal complexes were also evaluated for their in vitro antibacterial activity against some bacterial strains, such as Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus subtilus and Salmonella typhae. The antibacterial activity demonstrated that metal complexes are more antibacterial as compared to uncomplexed imines and parent antibiotic, The present study was carried out to search target antibiotic instead of broad spectrum.

TI Flow Injection Determination of Mo(VI), in Freshwaters with Luminol
   Chemiluminescence Detection
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID SPECTROPHOTOMETRIC DETERMINATION; TRACE AMOUNTS; ICP-AES; MOLYBDENUM;
   SAMPLES; PRECONCENTRATION; SEPARATION; SEAWATER; SPECTROMETRY; PHOSPHATE
AB A flow injection method is reported for the determination of Mo(VI) based on luminol chemiluminescence. The molybdophosphoric heteropoly acid formed by phosphate and ammonium molybdate in acidic conditions generated chemiluminescence emission due to the oxidation of luminol. The limit of detection was 0.5 ng mL(-1) with a sample throughput of 120 h(-1). A linear calibration graph was obtained over the range 1.0-200 ng mL(-1) (r(2) = 0.999 n = 9) with relative standard deviation (n = 4) in the range of 1.0-2.5%. Interfering cations were removed by passing the sample through an in-line immodiacetate-chelating column. Analysis of a coastal water certified reference material (CASS-3) for Mo(VI) gave good results (8.6 +/- 0.47 ng mL(-1) compared with certified value of 8.95 +/- 0.26 ng mL(-1)). The method was applied to freshwater samples and the recoveries of 95-105% Mo(VI) were observed.
C1 [Attiq-Ur-Rehman; Yaqoob, Mohammad; Waseem, Amir; Nabi, Abdul] Univ Balochistan, Dept Chem, Quetta, Pakistan.

TI Comparative Study of Biochemical Properties of 57 kDa and 100 kDa
   Zn-Dependent Acid Phosphatases in Chicken Heart and Liver
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID BOVINE BRAIN; PURIFICATION; MYO-INOSITOL-1-PHOSPHATASE
AB Two types of Zn(++)-dependent acid phosphatase based on differences in molecular size and tissue distribution have been purified. High molecular weight Zn(++)-dependent acid phosphatase (100 kDa) Peak-II from chicken liver was purified to homogeneity. 475-fold purification,as achieved with specific activity of 11 U/mg of protein. Low molecular weight Zn(++)-dependent acid phosphatase corresponding to 57 kDa from chicken heart was partially purified about 100 times with specific activity of 2.2 U/mg of protein and recovery of 5%. 57kDa Zn(++)-dependent acid phosphatase catalysed the hydrolysis of myo-inositol-1-phosphate in the presence of 3 mM Mg(++) at pH 7.2 while 100 kDa Zn(++)-dependent acid phosphatase did not hydrolyse. Thus 57kDa enzyme exhibits Mg(++)-dependent of myo-inositol-1-phsphatase activity. Both enzymes were studied for their substrate specificity, sensitivity to inhibitors and other kinetic parameters. High molecular weight enzyme hydrolysed the substrates to lesser extent than low molecular weight enzyme, The myo-inositol-1-PO(4) and myo-inositol-2-PO(4) were not hydrolysed by both enzymes in the presence of 5 mM Zn(++) at pH 6.0. Phosphate, tartrate and molybdate inhibited the enzymes competitively, 100 kDa enzyme was more sensitive to these inhibitors than 57 kDa enzyme. No other significant differences in the biochemical properties between the two enzymes were found.
C1 [Saeed, Asma; Shah, Abdul Haleem; Khan, Abdur Rahim] Gomal Univ, Dept Biol Sci, Dera Ismail Khan, Pakistan.
   [Naz, Rubina; Saeed, Ahmad] Gomal Univ, Dept Chem, Dera Ismail Khan, Pakistan.

TI Determination of 4-Nonylphenol, 2-Ethoxy Phenol, 4-Octyl Phenol and
   other Alkylphenols in Fish and Shellfish by GC-MS
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID NONYLPHENOLS; SEDIMENTS
AB This study presents the results of an investigation on the Occurrence of alkyl phenols (APs) and their ethoxylates (APEs) in edible marine species from lower James River, Chesapeake Bay along the Virginia Coast of Atlantic ocean. Shell fishery included Crab (Callinectes sapidus), Clam Merccnaria), Oyster (C. ariakensis), White Shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei) and eggs of flounder Plus eight fish species, striped bass (Morone saxatilis), Atlantic mackeral (Centropristis striate), Summer Flounder, (Paralichthys dentatus), bluefish (Pomatomus saltatrix), croaker (Micropogon undulatus), spotted sea trout (Cynoscion nebulosus), White perch (Morone americana), as well as Tilapia sp. and white shrimp from aquaculture center of Virginia Tech were analyzed for their content of nonylphenol (NP), octylphenol (OP) and 2-ehoxyphenol (OPEs). These compounds were found in all analyzed samples. NP was detected at the range of concentrations: 2.43-5.30 and 2.40-4.37 mu g g(-1) wet weight in shellfisheries and fishes respectively. OPE were found at respective levels of 0-4.21 and 0-2.35 mu g g(-1) wet weight in shellfisheries and fish. whereas OP was determined at respective concentrations of 0-3.0 and 2.60-3.02 mu g g(-1) weight in the same species.

TI Lysine Production by L-homoserine Resistant Mutant of Brevibacterium
   flavum
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID CORYNEBACTERIUM-GLUTAMICUM; SYSTEMS BIOLOGY; L-THREONINE;
   LACTOFERMENTUM; BIOSYNTHESIS; GROWTH; STRAIN
AB Brevibacterium flavum, an industrially important microorganism used for the production of lysine, was mutated chemically by iso-propyl-methane sulphonate to produce an auxotroph with increased yield of lysine. One of the mutant strain B. flavum AJ/SA-315 showing maximum lysine activity was selected after screening. Yeast sludge was fermented by this mutant strain of B. flavum to increase the lysine content. Maximum lysine concentration of about 57.2 mg/100 mL was achieved with 2% corn steep liquor. The amino acid profile of final microbial biomass protein showed that it was enriched with all essential amino acids, Fermentation of yeast Sludge with mutated B. flavum AJ/SA-315 enhanced the lysine content from 1.59% to 3.71%. The fermented samples can be a good source of lysine and other essential amino acids for use in synthetic feed.
C1 [Ali, Safdar; Ahmed, Sibtain; Sheikh, Munir Ahmad; Hashmi, Abu Saeed; Jamil, Amer] Univ Agr Faisalabad, Dept Chem & Biochem, Faisalabad 38040, Pakistan.
   [Ahmed, Sibtain; Hashmi, Abu Saeed] Univ Vet & Anim Sci, Dept Physiol & Biochem, Lahore 54000, Pakistan.
   [Rajoka, Mohammad Ibrahim] NIBGE, Faisalabad, Pakistan.

TI Nutritional Assessment of Morus alba and Phoenix dactylifera
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID CARDIOVASCULAR-DISEASE; DIETARY ANTIOXIDANTS; EDIBLE PLANTS; DATE PALM;
   FRUIT; TURKEY; NIGRA; RATS; L.
AB Dry fruits Morus alba and Phoenix dactylifera have been analyzed for their nutritional status. The dry fruits were obtained from the local market of Peshawar and were analyzed for their nutritional and anti-nutritional constituents. A study of proximate analysis, nutritional and anti-nutritional values and minerals composition was carried out on the given dry fruits. The values for moisture, ash, proteins, lipids, crude fiber, pectin, carbohydrates, and computed calorific values have been reported in the proximate analysis. Among nutritional components, vitamin B(2), vitamin C phosphate and total phenols were determined.
   Anti-nutritional analysis showed the presence of oxalic acid and alkaloids. The decreasing order of essential trace metal ions concentration was Fe > Cr > Cu > Pb > Ni. Both the fruits were found potential sources of essential nutrients. The results revealed that, if consumed as a part of human diet on regular basis, M. alba and P. dactylifera could provide rich sources of micro and macronutrients.

TI Effect of Aminoguanidine on Advanced Glycation End Products (AGEs) using
   Normal and Diabetic Plasma
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID NONENZYMATIC GLYCATION; CROSS-LINKING; PROTEINS; GLYCOSYLATION;
   ENDPRODUCTS; INHIBITORS; MELLITUS; COLLAGEN; GLUCOSE; UREMIA
AB The world is facing an explosive increase in the incidence of diabetes mellitus and cost-effective complementary therapies are needed. Protein glycation takes place when elevated levels of circulating reducing sugars react with amino groups in proteins, forming complex, often unstable, irreversible and reactive compounds "AGEs", a process that may take weeks or months to accomplish. In this study, glycation and AGES inhibition by aminoguanidine (synthetic inhibitor of AGES) weres investigated. Studies were performed by using normal and diabetic plasma with two incubation temperatures (37 degrees C & 50 degrees C). Samples were incubated for 5 weeks at both temperatures with varying concentrations of glucose and aminoguanidine. The results indicated that high temperature causes changes in protein structure that facilitate the AGES formation. The increase in fluorescence was observed from 1(st) to 5(th) week of incubation that indicated increase in glycation. Aminoguanidine at 10 mM level showed profound results towards AGES inhibition but in few cases results with 5 mM aminoguanidine are also comparable to 10 mM. AGES level increased from 3(rd) to 5(th) week of incubation when measured by ELISA. ELISA was found to be sensitive and reliable method to check AGES in diabetic and normal plasma as compared to fluorescence and aminoguanidine has the ability to decrease AGES production.
C1 [Kousar, Samina; Sheikh, Munir Ahmad; Asgher, Muhammad] Univ Agr Faisalabad, Dept Chem & Biochem, Faisalabad, Pakistan.
   [Sarwar, Muhammad] Univ Agr Faisalabad, Inst Anim Nutr & Feed Technol, Faisalabad, Pakistan.
RP Kousar, S (reprint author), Univ Agr Faisalabad, Dept Chem & Biochem, Faisalabad, Pakistan.

TI Bioconversion of Beet Pulp to Microbial Biomass Protein by Candida
   utilis
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID SINGLE-CELL PROTEIN; ASPERGILLUS-NIGER; YEAST; YIELD; FOOD; GROWTH
AB The present article describes a study of the microbial biomass protein production from beet pulp to improve its nutritional value as a feed stuff, Candida utilis has important characteristics for the economic production of microbial biomass protein and for its supplementation in poultry and livestock feeds. The optimal conditions for microbial biomass protein production from C. utilis were 3% (w/v) beet pulp, 0.0075% CaCl2 center dot 2H(2)O, 0.125% MgSO4 center dot 7H(2)O, 0.45% KH2PO4, 0.03% KCl at C: N ratio of 15:1 in the presence of 2% cane molasses and 1% corn steep liquor. The amino acid profile of final microbial biomass protein showed that it is enriched with all essential amino acids. The microbial biomass protein obtained could be employed in the protein enrichment of animal feed supplements.

TI Phytochemical Studies on Asphodelus tenuifolius
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID SPECTRA
AB Eight compounds have been isolated for the first time from Asphodelus tenuifolius namely, beta-sitosterol (1), 1-octacosanol (2), 1-triacontanol (3), hexadecanoic acid (4), tetracosanoic acid (5), triacontanoic acid (6). 3-hydroxybenzoic acid (7) and beta-sitosterol 3-O-beta-D-glucopyranoside (8), respectively. Their structures have been elucidated by EIMS, HREIMS, HRFABMS and NMR spectroscopic data.

TI Further Phytochemical Studies on Aerva persica
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID CONSTITUENT; COUMARINS; SPECTRA
AB Eleven compounds have been isolated for the first time from Aerva persica namely, beta-sitosterol (1), 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde (2), 4-hydroxybenzoic acid (3), 5,7-dimethoxycoumarin (4), 5,8-dihydroxycoumarin (5), 5,6,7-trimethoxycoumarin (6), 4-hydroxy-3,5-dimethoxybenzaldehyde (7), 3,4'-dihydroxy-3',5'-dimethoxypropiophenone (8), gallic acid (9), 5-hydroxy-3',4',6,7,8-pentamethoxyflavone (10) and beta-sitosterol 3-O-beta-D-glucopyranoside (11), respectively. Their structures have been elucidated by EIMS, HREIMS, FAB, HRFABMS and NMR spectroscopic data.

TI Lipids Classification of Mangifera indica Kernel Fat
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID PHOSPHOLIPIDS
AB The Mangifera indica (mango) kernel fat of 'Desi' variety (11.8%) was extracted and fractionated into neutral and polar lipids i.e., hydrocarbons, 0.4%, wax esters 1.0%, triterpene alcohol esters; 1.2%, sterol esters; 5.0% triglycerides; 82.6%, free fatty acids; 2.5%, diglycerides; 1.7%, sterols; 0.9% glycolipids, 1.4% monoglycerides; 2.0%, phosphatidylethanolamine; 0.4% phosphatidylcholines 0.6%, lyso-phosphatidylethanolamine; 0.2% and phosphatidylinositol; 0.1% The esterified lipid compounds were hydrolyzed to liberate fatty acids; C-12-C-24 which were converted into methyl esters. The methyl esters of liberated fatty acids were purified by thin layer chromatography and analyzed by gas liquid chromatography.

TI Genetic Similarity of Pakistani Pea (Pisum sativum L.) Germplasm with
   World Collection using Cluster Analysis and Jaccard's Similarity Index
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID SEED PROTEINS; SDS-PAGE; DIVERSITY; MARKERS; TRAITS; VIGNA
AB In the present study, 222 genotypes obtained from 37 countries of the world were evaluated through SDS-PAGE analysis to calculate genetic diversity and estimate genetic similarity of Pakistani pea germplasm with world collection. Genetic distances ranged from 0 to 71% were observed for the germplasm acquired from various countries, which showed broad base of genetic diversity. Cluster analysis and Jaccard's similarity index, identified three centers based on genetic diversity and proteomic homology; most diverse (Sweden, Netherlands, China, France, USA, Turkey, Mexico, ICARDA, UK, Pakistan, India, Ethiopia and Australia), moderate diverse (Peru, New Zealand, Germany, Syria, Czech, Paraguay and Iran) and least diverse (Jordon, Algeria, Morocco, Ecuador, Canada, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Guinea, Yugoslavia Nepal, Denmark, Norway, Poland, Lebanon, Iraq, Greece and Afghanistan). The centers will help in future genebank management and ultimately will enhance the utilization of available genetic resources for crop improvement.
C1 [Nisar, Muhammad; Subhan, Muhammad] Univ Sci & Technol, Fac Sci Appl, Dept Biotechnol, Bannu, NWFP, Pakistan.

TI Effect of Crosslinking in Textile Pigment Printing and Enhancement of
   Fastness Properties
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
AB Pigment printing was carried out on lab scale by simple screen-printing techniques. By the application of acrylate based binder and melamine based fixative the crocking, perspiration and dry-cleaning fastness properties of Red, Navy and Black prints were evaluated. It has been found that, as the concentration ratio between pigment applied and fixative increases, the fastness properties also increase and reach to an optimum value of 1:2.5; beyond this value the fastness properties decrease and resultant print become stiff. The fastness properties of Red print were found to be better as compared to Navy and Black prints.

TI Detection and Determination of Para-red in Chillies and Spices by HPLC
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID SUDAN DYES; HOT CHILI; AZO-DYES; CHROMATOGRAPHY; FOODS
AB A rapid High Pressure Liquid Phase Chromatography (HPLC) method was developed for the detection and determination of para-red in red chilli powder and other related food materials. The detection was made at 488 nm using a UV-VIS detector. The chromatographic separation was achieved on a reverse phase C-18 column with isocratic elution by using a mobile phase consisting of deionized water (200 ml containing 0.34 g KH2PO4) and HPLC grade methanol (800 ml containing 1.01 g tetraethylammonium bromide). The flow rate of mobile phase was maintained at I ml/min. The retention times were ranged between 15 to 20 min. Toluene was used for extraction to prepare sample. The standard was para-red. The method was in-house validated based on following criteria: Limit of detection (LOD), Limit of quantification (LOQ), recovery, repeatability and linearity. LOD and LOQ were upto I mg/kg and 3 mg/kg, respectively. The recovery values ranged between 97-99%. Repeatability and linearity obtained for para-red standard solutions were 1.91% (RSD, n = 7) and r(2) > 0.98888 (in the range of 1.0 to 100 mg/l), respectively.
C1 [Riaz, Naheed; Khan, Rashid Ali; Aziz-Ur-Rehman; Ali, Samar; Yasmeen, Shazia; Afza, Nighat] PCSIR Labs Complex, Pharmaceut Res Ctr, Karachi 75280, Pakistan.
RP Afza, N (reprint author), PCSIR Labs Complex, Pharmaceut Res Ctr, Karachi 75280, Pakistan.

TI Comparison of Liver Function Test in Symptomatic and Asymptomatic HCV
   Positive Patients
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID HEPATITIS-C VIRUS; ALANINE AMINOTRANSFERASE LEVELS; VOLUNTEER
   BLOOD-DONORS; NATURAL-HISTORY; INFECTION; CIRRHOSIS; ANTIBODY; OUTCOMES;
   THERAPY; QUALITY
AB Hepatitis C is a major health problem all over the world. Symptoms are few in acute phase while progression of the disease is unpredictable and evolves over decades. This study was undertaken with an aim to differentiate the hepatic parameters of symptomatic and asymptomatic HCV patients and compare it with the control group.
   In a retrospective study three groups of symptomatic, asymptomatic HCV patients and control were studied for their hepatic parameters, comprising 75 individuals in each.
   ALT was elevated in 78.7 %, AST in 70.6 %, GGT in 48 % and ALP was raised in 6.6 % of symptomatic HCV patients, respectively, whereas in asymptomatic patients ALT, AST, GGT and ALP was raised in 82.6 %, 65.3 %, 33.3 % and 21.3 %, respectively. Total protein, albumin, globulin, A/G ratio and serum bilirubin remained within normal limits.
   The ALT, AST and GGT levels were high in both patient groups but a slight more increase (P < 0.05) was noted in ALT and AST of symptomatic as compared to asymptomatic group. The GGT level in symptomatic and asymptornatic groups showed a non-significant difference (P > 0.05). The ALP level of asymptornatic HCV patients showed a slight more increase (P < 0.05) as compared to symptomatic HCV patients. All the results are based on comparison with the control group. Most common symptoms encountered were abdominal pain, fatigue, body and muscular pain in 35 %, 31 % and 15 %, symptomatic patients, respectively.
   A significant difference of P < 0.05 was noted for ALT, AST and ALP in the two patient groups.

TI Methotrexate Suppresses Substance P and CGRP in Adjuvant Arthritis in
   Rats
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID GENE-RELATED PEPTIDE; EARLY RHEUMATOID-ARTHRITIS; MECHANISM; INCREASE;
   INTERLEUKIN-10; INHIBITION
AB The mechanism by which methotrexate (MTX) produces its anti-inflammatory effect in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is not completely clear, The objective of this study was to investigate whether the anti-inflammatory effect of MTX is through its influence on the expression of sensory neuropeptides, substance P (SP) and calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) in ankle joints and dorsal root ganglia (DRG) of arthritic rats. Adjuvant arthritis was induced with heat-killed mycobacteria. One group of arthritic rats (n = 6) was treated with MTX (0.2 mg/kg body weight, subcutaneously) on every 4th day for a period of 18 weeks, while another group of arthritic rats (n=6) treated with physiological saline served as control. After 18-week treatment, animals were sacrificed and the inflamed ankle joints and corresponding DRG (L2-L6) were dissected and prepared for immunohistochemical analysis. The neuronal density of SP and CGRP immunoreactivity in ankle joints and DRG was assessed by semi-quantitative analysis. There was significant reduction in hind paw swelling and inflammation in the MTX-treated rats. SP- and CGRP-positive nerve fibres were significantly reduced (P<0.05) in ankle joints in MTX treated rats as compared to control rats. Similarly, CGRP-positive nerve cells in DRG were significantly decreased (P=0.0004) in rats treated with MTX as compared to controls. In rats with adjuvant arthritis, MTX significantly reduced CGRP expression in the ankle joints and their corresponding DRG and SP expression in ankle joints. Suppression of pro-inflammatory neuropeptides, SP and CGRP may be another mechanism by which MTX produces its anti-inflamimatory effect in arthritis.
C1 [Iqbal, Mohammad Perwaiz; Baig, Jawed Altaf] Aga Khan Univ, Dept Biol & Biomed Sci, Karachi 74800, Pakistan.
   [Ahmed, Mahmood; Rehman, Rasham; Qureshi, Ayaz Alam] Aga Khan Univ, Dept Surg, Karachi 74800, Pakistan.
RP Iqbal, MP (reprint author), Aga Khan Univ, Dept Biol & Biomed Sci, Karachi 74800, Pakistan.

   Ahmed M, 1998, J BONE JOINT SURG BR, V80B, P151, DOI 10.1302/0301-620X.80B1.8138

TI Significance of Vitamin C in Plants
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
AB Vitamins are essential for maintaining good health. They are required in very small amounts to act as co-enzymes of various enzymes. Common examples of vitamins are thiamine (vitamin 131) riboflavin (vitamin 132) and vitamin C. Vitamin C (chemically known as L-ascorbic acid) is a water-soluble nutrient, essential for life due to many metabolic functions and involvement in many enzymatic reactions. It is required for the development of cartilage, teeth and bones, healing of wounds and aiding the absorption of iron from intestine [1]. Since it undergoes reversible oxidation-reduction, therefore vitamin C also plays a role in cellular respiration. In human it is not synthesized by the organs, it is important to include vitamin C in one's daily diet [2, 3]. Vitamin C is widely used in pharmaceutical, chemical, cosmetics and food industry and is also added in manufactured food for antioxidation to conserve for a long time [4, 5]. The deficiency of vitamin C can lead to many diseases [6]. A severe form of vitamin C deficiency is known as scurvy [7]. Variety of methods including titration, potentiometry, voltametry, HPLC, coulmetry and spectrophotometry are applied for the determination of vitamin C [8]. To suggest that medicinal plant and flowers could be used as a source of vitamin C, the present work was carried out.

TI Catalytic Decomposition of Ponceau S for the Kinetic Spectrophotometric
   Determination of Gallium (III)
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID PLASMA-MASS SPECTROMETRY; INDIUM; HEMATOXYLIN; SAMPLES
AB A new kinetic spectrophotometric method has been proposed for the determination of gallium (III) at trace levels. The method is based on the catalytic decomposition of Ponceau S. The reaction is monitored spectrophotometrically at 5 18 nm in acidic medium after 1.50 minute from the addition of oxidant. Effect of ponceim S, potassium bromate and sulphuric acid have been investigated on catalysed and uncatalysed reactions. The interfering effect of different cations is decreased by addition of EDTA as a masking agent. At optimized conditions the method indicates a linear calibration range of 0.5 to 2.5 mu g/mL of gallium (III), The method has been examined for the analysis of test solutions of gallium with relative % error within +/- 2.5 %. The reproducibility for the analysis of 2.0 mu g/mL (n=10) was observed with coefficient of variation within 4.5 %. A sample of drug and a semiconductor were analysed for gallium and results correlated with independent spectrophotometric method.
C1 [Khuhawar, Muhammad Yar] Univ Sindh, High Tech Cent Resources Lab, Jamshoro 76080, Pakistan.
   [Mahar, Khalida Parveen; Mastoi, Ghulam Mustafa] Univ Sindh, Dr MA Kazi Inst Chem, Jamshoro 76080, Pakistan.
   [Kazi, Tasneem Gul] Univ Sindh, Natl Ctr Excellence Analyt Chem, Jamshoro 76080, Pakistan.

TI The Role of Cholesterol in Atherosclerosis: Possibilities of Herbal
   Treatment Options
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF PAKISTAN
LA English
DT Article
ID CORONARY-ARTERY-DISEASE; LOW-DENSITY-LIPOPROTEIN; OXIDATIVE STRESS;
   CAROTID ATHEROSCLEROSIS; CARDIOVASCULAR-DISEASE; ENDOTHELIAL FUNCTION;
   CLINICAL-PRACTICE; HEART-DISEASE; INFLAMMATION; LDL
AB Disturbance of homeostasis in the body can cause several life-threatening diseases and atherosclerosis is one of them. Among various life threatening diseases, atherosclerosis is a major cause of deaths mainly through myocardial infarction in all over the world. Clinical and experimental results clearly suggest the relationship between hypercholesterolemia and atherosclerosis. Although there are many commercial drugs available for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia but limited beneficial effects are associated with them and mostly have varied scale of side effects. Traditional herbal therapy is a good alternative treatment which has proved their efficacy through the time course of millenniums. The need is just to divert the mindset of governments and investors to develop this field by investing a comparable amount of money. Nature has provided a remedy for every problem it created and it is our duty to explore it without violating the rules of nature.

TI Study on the Role of Metal Oxides in Desulphurization of Some Petroleum
   Fractions
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHINESE CHEMICAL SOCIETY
LA English
DT Article
DE Petroleum; Sulfur; Environment; Distillates; Oxides
ID DEEP DESULFURIZATION; LEAD MERCAPTIDES; SULFUR-COMPOUNDS; METHANETHIOL;
   ADSORPTION; EXTRACTION; CHEMISTRY; SURFACES; FUEL
AB Metal oxides are highly reactive towards the compounds of sulphur, particularly thioles. A comparative study was made of the desulphurization potential of various metal oxides such as MnO2, PbO2, ArO3, Al2O3, MgO2, ZnO2 and silica on reaction with Jhal Magsi crude oil and its distillate fractions, i.e., kerosene and diesel oil. The effect of time was also studied and the desulphurization was performed for time durations of one hour, three hours and six hours. The analysis of the residual fractions indicated that significant sulphur depletion occurred with lead oxide and manganese dioxide in the one-hour and three-hour reaction times in all three samples. Lead oxide (PbO2) brought about a maximum desulphurization of 60.28% in the case of crude oil, 54.54% in the case of diesel oil and 52.57% in the case of kerosene oil in a 01 h reaction time. Similarly, manganese oxide (MnO2) caused a maximum desulphurization of 58.55% in the case of crude oil, 49.38% in the case of diesel oil and 53.30% in case of kerosene oil in a 3 h reaction time. The rest of the metal oxides also exhibited good sulphur removal activity, but their performance is not as noteworthy as in the cases of PbO2 and MnO2.
C1 [Shakirullah, M.; Ahmad, Imtiaz; Ishaq, M.; Ahmad, Waqas] Univ Peshawar, Inst Chem Sci, NWFP, Peshawar 25120, Pakistan.
RP Ahmad, I (reprint author), Univ Peshawar, Inst Chem Sci, NWFP, Peshawar 25120, Pakistan.

TI Simultaneous Determination of Paracetamol and Orphenadrine Citrate in
   Dosage Formulations and in Human Serum by RP-HPLC
SO JOURNAL OF THE CHINESE CHEMICAL SOCIETY
LA English
DT Article
DE Paracetamol; Orphenadrine citrate; Propylparaben sodium; RP-HPLC; UV
   detection
ID PERFORMANCE LIQUID-CHROMATOGRAPHY; MAJOR METABOLITES; ACETAMINOPHEN;
   PLASMA; URINE; ASSAY
AB Rapid liquid chromatographic procedures are proposed for analysis of paracetamol and orphenadrine citrate in pharmaceutical preparations and human serum using acetonitrile: water (50:50) as a mobile phase, adjusting pH to 2.6, UV detection at 215 nm and propylparaben sodium as internal standard. The advantages of this method include good and rapid separation, well resolved peaks, and only a small amount of sample is required for assay and adequate precision. The method showed good linearity in the range of 6 to 10000 ng/mL for paracetamol serum concentrations with a correlation coefficient 0.9999 (inter and intra clay CV < 3.15) and in the range 3-10000 ng/mL for orphenadrine citrate serum concentrations with a correlation coefficient of 0.9999 (inter and intra day CV < 3.58). The recovery of paracetamol and orphenadrine citrate was > 96.9% and > 96.7%, respectively. The proposed method may be used for the quantitative analysis of paracetamol and orphenadrine citrate alone or in combination from raw materials, in bulk drugs, dosage formulations and in serum.
C1 [Arayne, M. Saeed; Siddiqui, Farhan Ahmed] Univ Karachi, Dept Chem, Karachi 75270, Pakistan.
   [Sultana, Najma] Univ Karachi, Fac Pharm, Dept Pharmaceut Chem, Karachi 75270, Pakistan.

TI Performance improvement of complementary feeders using static transfer
   switch system
SO JOURNAL OF ZHEJIANG UNIVERSITY-SCIENCE A
LA English
DT Article
DE Complementary feeder; Cross current; Static transfer switch (STS);
   Sensitive load; Voltage sag; PSCAD/EMTDC
AB The performance of complementary feeders, running in parallel, can be significantly improved by installing static transfer switches (STSs) at critical locations. We develop the STS control logic, which transfers the critical load from the preferred feeder to the alternate feeder when a voltage sag or a fault occurs on the preferred feeder. A forced commutation technique is proposed and implemented to turn off the preferred feeders' thyristor, thus avoiding cross current to flow and minimizing the transfer time. Simulation results show that the forced commutation technique is more effective as compared to the recently proposed time delay technique for STS operation. Two different feeders, namely New Exchange, the preferred feeder, and Sector I-10/2, the alternate feeder of Islamabad Electric Supply COmpany (IESCO), Pakistan, have been selected for case studies. The software PSCAD/EMTDC professional package has been used for simulation.
C1 [Mahmood, Tahir; Choudhry, Mohammad Ahmad] Univ Engn & Technol, Dept Elect Engn, Taxila 47050, Pakistan.
RP Mahmood, T (reprint author), Univ Engn & Technol, Dept Elect Engn, Taxila 47050, Pakistan.
EM tahir_m@uettaxila.edu.pk

TI Anti-allergic effects of ethanol extracts from brown seaweeds
SO JOURNAL OF ZHEJIANG UNIVERSITY-SCIENCE B
LA English
DT Article
DE Anti-allergic activity; Brown seaweed; Ethanol extracts; Hyaluronidase
   Phlorotannin
ID MAST-CELLS; HISTAMINE-RELEASE; INHIBITORY-ACTIVITY; HYALURONIDASE;
   HYPERSENSITIVITY; ACTIVATION; PHLOROTANNINS; INFLAMMATION; DEGRADATION;
   ALLERGEN
AB Ethanol extracts of brown seaweeds from Pakistan and China were isolated and compared for their antiallergenic activities. They included Sargassum tennerimum (ST) and Sargassum cervicorne (SC) from Pakistan, and Sargassum graminifolium turn (SG), Sargassum thunbergii (STH), and Laminaria japonica (LJ) from China. The ethanol extracts of these brown seaweeds were optimized at 85% (v/v) ethanol for the maximum yield of phlorotannin, an inhibitor against hyaluronidase. Total phlorotannins contained in the crude extracts were measured as 1.71% (SG), 0.74% (STH), 0.97% (LJ), 3.30% (SC), and 5.06% (ST). The 50% inhibitory concentrations (IC50) of Pakistani SC and ST were 109.5 and 21 mu g/ml, respectively, lower than those of Chinese SG, STH, and LJ (134, 269, and 148 mu g/ml, respectively). An antiallergic drug, disodium cromoglycate (DSCG), had an IC50=39 mu g/ml, and a natural inhibitor of hyaluronidase, catechin, had an IC50=20 mu g/ml. The IC50 of ST extract was found similar to that of catechin (21 vs 20 mu g/ml) and lower than that of DSCG (21 vs 39 mu g/ml). This suggests that ST is a potent inhibitor of hyaluronidase, indicating a promising future development of natural antiallergic medicines or functional foods.

TI Effect of derivatization of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim with
   copper and zinc on their medicinal value
SO MEDICINAL CHEMISTRY RESEARCH
LA English
DT Article
DE Copper complexes; Zinc complexes; Antibacterials; Schiff base complexes;
   Sulfamethoxazole; Trimethoprim
ID BIOLOGICAL EVALUATION; COMPLEXES; CEPHALEXIN
AB Cu(II) and Zn(II) complexes of Schiff bases obtained by condensation of sulfamethoxazole with salicylaldehyde/pyridoxal were prepared and characterized by microanalytical, thermogravimetric, magnetic, and spectroscopic data. The Cu (II) and Zn (II) complexes of salicylidenesulfamethoxazole were found to be five coordinate while all others were six coordinate. The electron paramagnetic resonance spectral lines exhibited rhombic distortion from axial symmetry, with g (aEuro-) > g (aSyen) > g (e), in the case of the Cu (II) complexes. The geometry of the complexes appears to be square-pyramidal or octahedral. All the compounds under investigation possess antibacterial activity against the strains tested. The antibacterial activity showed the following trend: Cu (II) complexes > Zn (II) complexes > Schiff base ligands > parent drugs. All the copper complexes were found to be active against kaolin paw edema whereas the parent drugs were inactive.

TI LOW PROFILE AND COMPACT SIZE COPLANAR UWB ANTENNA WORKING FROM 2.8 GHz
   TO OVER 40 GHz

LA English

DE UWB; low profile; compact antenna; omnidirectional
ID MONOPOLE ANTENNA

AU Nafees, M

   Jan, Mohamad Rasul
TI Circulatory Land Tenure and Its Social and Ecological Impacts
SO MOUNTAIN RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT
LA English
DT Article
DE Circulatory land tenure; soli conservation; Malakand district; Swat
   districts; North West Frontier Province (NWFP); Pakistan
ID DEGRADATION; COMMUNITY; RIGHTS
AB This study explores the social and ecological impacts of circulatory land tenure in the villages of Allahdand and Dheri, situated near one another in the lower Swat valley (upper part of Malakand Agency). Apart from communal hill slopes, agricultural land is divided Into 3 categories: damanl (rain fed), Jewardara (irrigated but with no rice), and shoulgarey (irrigated, mainly used for rice). The people permanently own. the rain fed land, while the irrigated land is under a tenure system known as garzinda wesh (circulatory tenure), with 10 years' tenure rotation allotted through khasanray (drawing lot). This type of land tenure system also exists partially in other villages of Upper Malakand such as Jolagaram, Khar, and Totakan. This system was introduced in the 16th century with the idea of sharing all types of land-including irrigated land, fertile land, slope land, etc-in equal shares and with the aim of enabling the landowner tribe to respond collectively if some other tribe or majority tenants tried to seize any portion of land. Due to social conflicts, this system can have negative impacts today, especially in the form of soil erosion leading to land degradation. We highlight the positive and negative environmental impacts of the system. To this purpose, a detailed survey was conducted using focus group interviews, participatory rural appraisals, mapping, and transit walks with timelines. The results show how social response to the suitability of the system for livelihoods and social integrity can vary. The impact on fuelwood consumption Is negative, leading to deforestation and lack of soil conservation. Abolishment of garzinda wesh in the village Is recommended.
C1 [Nafees, Mohammad; Khan, Hizbullah] Univ Peshawar, Dept Environm Sci, Peshawar 25120, Pakistan.
   [Jan, Mohamad Rasul] Univ Peshawar, Inst Chem Sci, Peshawar 25120, Pakistan.

TI A common MYBPC3 (cardiac myosin binding protein C) variant associated
   with cardiomyopathies in South Asia
SO NATURE GENETICS
LA English
DT Article
ID FAMILIAL HYPERTROPHIC CARDIOMYOPATHY; SPLICE DONOR SITE; GENE;
   MUTATIONS; IDENTIFICATION; INDIA; PHOSPHORYLATION; IMPAIRMENT; MUTANTS;
   DOMAIN
AB Heart failure is a leading cause of mortality in South Asians. However, its genetic etiology remains largely unknown(1). Cardiomyopathies due to sarcomeric mutations are a major monogenic cause for heart failure (MIM600958). Here, we describe a deletion of 25 bp in the gene encoding cardiac myosin binding protein C (MYBPC3) that is associated with heritable cardiomyopathies and an increased risk of heart failure in Indian populations (initial study OR 5.3 (95% CI = 2.3-13), P = 2 x 10(-6); replication study OR = 8.59 (3.19-25.05), P = 2 x 10(-8); combined OR = 6.99 (3.68-13.57), P = 4 x 10(-11)) and that disrupts cardiomyocyte structure in vitro. Its prevalence was found to be high (similar to 4%) in populations of Indian subcontinental ancestry. The finding of a common risk factor implicated in South Asian subjects with cardiomyopathy will help in identifying and counseling individuals predisposed to cardiac diseases in this region.
C1 [Rani, Deepa Selvi; Singh, Lalji; Thangaraj, Kumarasamy] Ctr Cellular & Mol Biol, Hyderabad 500007, Andhra Pradesh, India.

TI Flow of a generalized second-grade fluid between two side walls
   perpendicular to a plate with a fractional derivative model
SO NONLINEAR ANALYSIS-REAL WORLD APPLICATIONS
LA English
DT Article
DE exact solutions; generalized second-grade fluid; fractional calculus
ID MODIFIED DARCYS-LAW; OLDROYD-B FLUID; MAXWELL MODEL; VISCOELASTIC FLUID;
   STARTING SOLUTIONS; 2ND-ORDER FLUID; MHD FLOW; MOTION; GRADE
AB In this paper, the exact analytic Solutions are obtained for flow of a generalized second-grade fluid between two side walls perpendicular to a plate. The fractional calculus approach in the constitutive relationship model of a non-Newtonian fluid is used. The exact analytic solutions are constructed by using Fourier sine transforms and the discrete Laplace transform of the sequential fractional derivatives. The Solutions for a second-grade fluid appear as the limiting cases of the presented Solutions on taking beta = 1. Moreover, in the absence of side walls, all solutions that have been obtained reduce to those corresponding to the motion over all infinite plate. (c) 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 [Khan, Masood] Quaid I Azam Univ, Dept Math, Islamabad 45320, Pakistan.
   [Wang, Shaowei] Peking Univ, Coll Engn, Dept Mech & Aerosp Engn, Beijing 100871, Peoples R China.

TI A note on some solutions for the flow of a fourth grade fluid in a
   porous space
SO NONLINEAR ANALYSIS-REAL WORLD APPLICATIONS
LA English
DT Article
DE fourth grade fluid; porous space; modified Darcy's law; time dependent
   flow; analytical solution
ID OLDROYD-B FLUID; MODIFIED DARCYS-LAW; HALF-SPACE; MHD FLOW
AB This paper investigates the time independent unidirectional flow of a fourth grade fluid filling the porous half space. Flow modelling is based upon a modified Darcy's law. Travelling wave and conditional symmetry Solutions are developed. The graphs are plotted and discussed for the sundry parameters. (C) 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 [Mambili-Mamboundou, H.; Mahomed, F. M.] Univ Witwatersrand, Sch Computat & Appl Math, Ctr Differential Equat Continuum Mech & Applicat, ZA-2050 Wits, Johannesburg, South Africa.

TI Some new extragradient iterative methods for variational inequalities
SO NONLINEAR ANALYSIS-THEORY METHODS & APPLICATIONS
LA English
DT Article
DE Variational inequalities; Extragradient method; Fixed point;
   alpha-inverse strongly monotone
ID NONEXPANSIVE-MAPPINGS; STRONG-CONVERGENCE; MONOTONE MAPPINGS;
   WEAK-CONVERGENCE; ALGORITHMS; THEOREMS
AB In this paper, we suggest and analyze some new extragradient iterative methods for finding the common element of the fixed points of a nonexpansive mapping and the solution set of the variational inequality for an inverse strongly monotone mapping in a Hilbert space. We also consider the strong convergence of the proposed method tinder some mild conditions. Several special cases are also discussed. Results proved in this paper may be viewed as improvement and refinement of the previously known results. (C) 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

TI POLLEN FLORA OF PAKISTAN - LXI. VIOLACEAE
SO PAKISTAN JOURNAL OF BOTANY
LA English
DT Article
AB Pollen morphology of 5 species of the family Violaceae from Pakistan has been examined by light and scanning electron microscope. Pollen grains are usually radially symmetrical, isopolar, colporate, sub-prolate to prolate-spheroidal. Sexine slightly thicker or thinner than nexine. Tectum mostly densely punctate rarely psilate. On the basis of exine pattern two distinct pollen types viz., Viola pilosa-type and Viola stocksii-type are recognized.

RP Perveen, A (reprint author), Univ Karachi, Dept Bot, Karachi 75270, Pakistan.

TI TISSUE CULTURE OF GERBERA
SO PAKISTAN JOURNAL OF BOTANY
LA English
DT Article
ID PLANT-REGENERATION; JAMESONII
AB Gerbera (Gerbera jamesonii) somatic tissues and seeds were tried for raising tissue cultures. The explants of shoot tips, immature inflorescences, leaf sections, capitulum explants, axillary buds and receptacles explants from field grown plants had contamination problems. Another trouble was slow growth of explant cultures as they were treated with sterilizing chemicals which damage their growing regions. However, callusing was in all explants and shoot regenerations were obtained from shoot tip and axillary buds. The calluses were obtained from clean seeds which were presoaked (20mg/liter for six hours) in colchicine for induction of polyploidy. The germinating seedlings were crushed and tissue mass was put on callusing medium containing MS with BA+2,4-D (each 3 mg/liter). After six weeks, the calli were transferred to MS+BA (4mg/liter) + IBA (1mg/liter). The developed plantlets were separated and cultured on MS containing BA and IBA (each @ 0.5mg/liter). The plantlets were transferred to pots under 100% humidity during initial weaning period, acclimatized and grown as normal plants.
C1 [Altaf, Nafees; Khan, Abdul Rehman; Ali, Liaqat; Bhatti, Inksar Ahmad] Nucl Inst Agr & Biol, Faisalabad, Pakistan.

TI ETHNOMEDICINAL STUDIES ON PLANT RESOURCES OF TEHSIL SHAKARGARH, DISTRICT
   NAROWAL, PAKISTAN
SO PAKISTAN JOURNAL OF BOTANY
LA English
DT Article
ID HILLS
AB The present research work was designed to gather indigenous knowledge of local people especially medicinal healers (Hakims) about traditional and medicinal uses of plants. Present study was confined to interview people of remote villages of tehsil Shakargarh, district Narowal, Pakistan from September 2003- August 2004. Indigenous knowledge was collected by interviewing people of different age groups between 40 to 80 years. Frequent field trips were arranged to record local information. A total of 102 species belonging to 93 genera and 62 families were recorded as being used by local inhabitants for various purposes such as fuel, furniture, fodder, making baskets and mats, brushing teeth, medicinal, vegetables and edible fruits.

TI INDIGENOUS MEDICINAL PLANTS USED BY LOCAL WOMEN IN SOUTHERN HIMALAYAN
   REGIONS OF PAKISTAN
SO PAKISTAN JOURNAL OF BOTANY
LA English
DT Article
AB The present work is based on the results of research conducted on traditional uses of some important plants by the local women in southern Himalayan Mountains, Pakistan. The locals especially women of the area have been using the medicinal plants for many day to day uses for various ailments and are dependent on the plants in their surroundings for food, health, medication and various cultural purposes. A total of 28 important plant species belonging to 25 families were recorded which were used medicinally and various other purposes by the local women. About 130 informants were interviewed in this regard. Mostly plants like Viburnum foetens Decne., Bergenia ciliata (Haw.) Sternb. Berberis lycium Royle, Geranium wallichianum D. Don ex Sweet and Skimmia laureola (DC.) Sieb. & Zucc. ex Walp. are used by the local women for medication, health care and other purposes. Geranium wallichianum D. Don ex Sweet is most commonly used as tonic by women especially for body strength and other internal body disorders. Bergenia ciliata (Haw.) Sternb., is used as anticancerous plant and for internal wounds. Skimmia laureola (DC.) Sieb. & Zucc. ex Walp. is another widely used plant for respiratory disorders in children by the local women. People have strong faith in herbal medication by ethnomedicinal plants and women are leading men in applying the recipe for medication by these plants.

   [Abbas, Ghulam] OGDC Head Off Islamabad, Well Dept, Islamabad, Pakistan.
   [Batool, Aniqa] PMAS Arid Agr Univ, Dept Environm Sci, Rawalpindi, Pakistan.

TI TOXIC EFFECTS OF LEAD AND CADMIUM ON GERMINATION AND SEEDLING GROWTH OF
   ALBIZIA LEBBECK (L.) BENTH
SO PAKISTAN JOURNAL OF BOTANY
LA English
DT Article
ID HEAVY-METALS; TOLERANCE; SOIL; CD; PB
AB The effects of lead and cadmium on seed germination, seedling, root, shoot length and seedling dry biomass of Albizia lebbeck was evaluated under laboratory conditions with and without lead and cadmium treatments. Lead and cadmium treatments at 10, 30, 50, 70 and 90 mu mol/L affected seed germination and seedling growth of A. lebbeck as compared to control. Lead treatments at 10, 30, 50, 70 and 90 mu mol/L concentrations produced significant (p<0.05) effects on seed germination and seedling length of A. lebbeck while lead treatment at 50 mu mol/L significantly affected root growth and seedling dry biomass as compared to control. Similarly, cadmium treatments from 10 to 90 mu mol/L affected the seed germination, root, shoot length and seedling dry biomass of A. lebbeck as compared to control. Seedlings vigor index of A. lebbeck showed gradual decrease with increase in concentration of lead and cadmium. Cadmium treatments showed adverse effects on seedlings of A. lebbeck as compared to lead. Lead and cadmium treatments at 90 mu mol/L exhibited lowest percentage of tolerance in seedlings of A. lebbeck as compared to control.
C1 [Farooqi, Z. R.; Iqbal, M. Zafar; Kabir, M.; Shafiq, M.] Univ Karachi, Dept Bot, Karachi 75270, Pakistan.
